skill.name: dispatching-parallel-agents
skill.description: Use when facing 3+ independent failures that can be investigated without shared state or dependencies. Dispatches multiple Claude agents to investigate and fix independent problems concurrently.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and templates. No executable code, no network calls, no filesystem access beyond standard tool usage. Safe for publication.

content.user_title: Dispatch parallel agents for independent problems
content.value_statement: When multiple independent failures occur across different system areas, investigating them sequentially wastes time. This skill provides templates and patterns to dispatch multiple Claude agents concurrently, reducing resolution time by up to 3x while preventing agent conflicts.
actual_capabilities: Identifies independent problem domains suitable for parallel investigation
Creates scoped agent tasks with clear boundaries and constraints
Dispatches multiple agents concurrently using Task tool
Defines output formats for result integration
Prevents agent conflicts through scope constraints
Provides templates for failure analysis and agent prompts
limitations: Requires problems to be truly independent with no shared state dependencies
Agents cannot access shared context during parallel execution
Not suitable when root causes are interconnected or cascading
Allows Read, Glob, Grep, Task, Bash tools only

use_cases.title: Parallel Test Failure Resolution
use_cases.description: Investigate and fix multiple failing tests across different modules simultaneously to reduce test fix cycles

use_cases.title: Distributed System Debugging
use_cases.description: Diagnose errors in separate microservices or infrastructure components at the same time

use_cases.title: Concurrent Bug Fixing
use_cases.description: Address multiple unrelated bugs in different parts of the codebase in parallel

prompt_templates.title: Basic Parallel Dispatch
prompt_templates.prompt: Task(Agent 1: Auth) || Task(Agent 2: API) || Task(Agent 3: Database)

prompt_templates.title: Problem Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a table listing each failing file/area, the specific problem, and whether it is independent from others. Mark problems as independent only if they have no shared dependencies or state.

prompt_templates.title: Agent Task Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: For each independent problem, create an agent task with: Scope (specific files/directories), Goal (clear objective), and Constraints (what not to modify).

prompt_templates.title: Result Integration
prompt_templates.prompt: After all agents complete, compile a results document showing: each agent, the root cause found, files modified, and test results. Highlight any conflicts or overlaps.

output_examples.input: Three tests failed: auth.test.js (JWT validation), api.test.js (routing), and db.test.js (connection timeout). All seem unrelated.
output: ✅ Agent 1 (Auth): Fixed JWT expiration calculation in auth/jwt.js:45 - Tests pass
✅ Agent 2 (API): Corrected middleware order in api/routes.js:12 - Tests pass
✅ Agent 3 (Database): Adjusted connection pool settings in db/config.js:8 - Tests pass
All three issues resolved in parallel with zero conflicts.

best_practices: Define narrow, specific scopes for each agent to prevent overlap and conflicts
Ensure each problem is truly independent with no shared state before dispatching
Specify clear constraints in each agent task describing what NOT to modify
anti_patterns: Dispatching agents on problems that share dependencies or can cascade-fix each other
Leaving agent scopes too broad, allowing modification of unrelated code
Failing to define what each agent should NOT touch

faq.question: How many agents can I dispatch in parallel?
faq.answer: The skill suggests 3+ independent failures. The actual limit depends on your Claude Code configuration and system resources.

faq.question: What tools do dispatched agents have access to?
faq.answer: This skill allows Read, Glob, Grep, Task, and Bash tools. Other tools like Edit require explicit permission.

faq.question: Can agents share files or context during execution?
faq.answer: No. Each agent operates independently with its own scope. Plan shared information needs before dispatching.

faq.question: How do I prevent agents from modifying the same files?
faq.answer: Define mutually exclusive scopes for each agent. Explicitly list allowed files and add constraints against touching certain areas.

faq.question: When should I NOT use parallel agent dispatch?
faq.answer: Avoid when failures are connected, require shared context, or when one fix might affect others. Use sequential investigation instead.

faq.question: How is this different from regular Task usage?
faq.answer: Regular Task handles one problem sequentially. This skill provides patterns for dispatching multiple independent tasks simultaneously.
